p: Consistently, a retrospective, multicenter study including 191 patients with COVID-19 illustrated that elevated hs-cTnI levels were evidenced in 17% of the whole cohort and those myocardial injuries mainly occurred in nonsurvivors (59% vs. 1%, p < 0.0001) [ 7]. A meta-analysis of six studies with 1527 COVID-19 patients found that at least 8% of the patients suffered from acute myocardial injury and the risk of myocardial injury was 13-fold higher in severe patients than nonsevere patients [ 20].
